results.title: After Proust
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, John Baxter and Galadriel Films
results.brief_description: A fleeting encounter between a man and a woman is treated in a romantic fashion. Set in Edwardian Sydney, the film is intended to suggest the atmosphere of the period and the narrative style of Marcel Proust.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McGill, John Baxter and Galadriel Films

results.title: After prison, what?
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Portrays the difficulties experienced by a man who wants to go straight but is unable to get work because he has a prison record. Day after day Charles Brown answers the want ads but employers will not hire an ex-convict. Doubts and fears beset him - he is sincere in his desire to work at the trade he learned in the penitentiary and yet society will not trust him. Eventually, before he falls into his old ways, the John Howard Society secures a job for him where he can take his place in society and regain his self-respect. Film award: Canadian Film Awards.

results.title: After Cook
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A look at the Australian people, their character, attitudes, and way of life. Australians, in the city and the bush, are examined both at home and while enjoying their favourite pastimes. Note: A short version of 28 minutes, intended mainly for overseas viewers, was also produced, entitled ‘Everything under the sun. Commentator: John Meillon.

results.title: Stand on your head
results.brief_description:
Stand on your head
This is a film about aging, attitude’and yoga.
Come on a journey to the centre of a suburban yoga class to witness elderly women, some in their nineties, practising yoga. Though they no longer stand on their heads, they do turn society’s perception of the elderly on its head
This film documents how yoga has helped these women keep physically and mentally strong despite their ageing years. The sense of community that coming to the same teacher for over thirty years has given them has also helped them cope with life’s challenges. The film centres on Edka, who maintains that yoga has helped her overcome many tragedies in her life, including the death of her husband and daughter.
By placing a local, multicultural group of ageing women in the spotlight, it is hoped that Stand on your Head can provide a positive role model for other senior citizens.
This ‘no-budget’ film was made in Melbourne by local documentary filmmaker, Naomi Wise. The music featured in the film is an old European Jewish folk tune. Indian instruments are used to reflect the curious mix of cultures in the film. It was arranged by Melbourne music producer Adam Starr and sung in Yiddish by Karen Feldman.

results.title: After all, you're the supervisor
results.creator_credit: Harvey Laidman, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Outlines methods to assist a worker in an office environment when transferring into a managerial and supervisory position. Focuses on the value of planning, scheduling and allocating work, the importance of liaising with senior management, personnel management and discipline, evaluating suggestions, identifying problems and analysing staff needs.

results.title: Africans all
results.creator_credit: Greg Knowles, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: A vast land of contradictions seen by plane from Algiers to Capetown, its varied history, primitive in the south and highly civilized in the north. The wide range of climatic and geographical conditions and their effect on the way of life. Thriving cosmopolitan cities and tiny villages; jungle growth; desert; mineral wealth and arid lands, people black and white; all are part of the African continent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Knowles, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: African odyssey: the two worlds of Musembe
results.creator_credit: Albert Waller and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: The two worlds of 11 year-old Musembe are the two worlds of 20th century Africa: the modern city where Musembe and his parents live in a large apartment building, and the primitive village where his civil servant father was born. A journey “home” - back to the family’s village - shows us the natural beauty of Kenya and gives a very human insight into the decisions which confront many Africans today. Musembe feels drawn to the village, and the tribal customs but his father reminds him, “We are city people now”, and we realize the emotional conflicts which come with rapid social change.

results.title: Celebration: the Larwill Tapestry
results.brief_description: Established by the State Government of Victoria in 1976, the Victorian Tapestry Workshop has garnered itself an international reputation as a leader in the industry. In 1999 the Government decided to present a gift to the new Singapore Esplanade Theatre and visual artist David Larwill was selected to create a design that would be turned into a tapestry. This documentary covers the process of creating the tapestry, warping the loom, dying the wool, hitching on, interpreting the artwork, hitching off and the cutting off ceremony. Includes a biography of the artist and his work, as well as a brief spiel on the artist exchange program involving 3 Singapore artists, culminating in an exhibition at the Victorian College of the Arts. Sue Walker, Director, Victorian Tapestry Workshop is also interviewed on her involvement in the project.

results.title: Seaside searching
results.brief_description:
Seaside Searching consists of interviews with ‘traditional’ local residents about St Kilda and surrounds and how the area is changing, in the context of 100 years history. Speakers include working girls, homeless, welfare workers, and aboriginal residents. While the technical quality is not great, vision and sound are clear.
At first the viewer is not sure where the journey is going, and whether the speakers’ words will be enough to hold our attention given the relative lack of visual stimulation. However as the program continues we are drawn in and held by the honesty, openness and truth of what we hear. The exterior interview locations grow on the viewer as markers of place. We realise that these uneducated or unsophisticated voices are saying important and meaningful things about community, change, class and status, and how regional social change affects the individual. By the close, one likes and believes in these ‘ordinary people’, and learns the value of community voices irrespective of their apparent form.

results.title: African odyssey: the red bicycle
results.creator_credit: Albert Waller and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: The travels of a red bicycle, assembled in Nairobi, enable us to learn about economic life in Africa, as it passes to a succession of owners. A tribal chief visiting the city buys it for his son and takes it back to his village in the bush. Subsequently, it is acquired by a young farmer, a government coffee tester, some tourists on safari, and eventually returned to the original village, where its parts are broken up and shared by everyone.
